text: CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: TITLE

text: CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: About this series: The climate crisis is intensifying humanitarian emergencies around the world and
label: BODY

text: humanitarians are increasingly having to incorporate climate data and forecasts into their analysis
label: BODY

text: and planning. This guidance series has been developed to help humanitarians to access, analyze and
label: BODY

text: interpret common types of climate and weather data, and to provide a common language for working
label: BODY

text: with meteorological and hydrological services.
label: BODY

text: •	 Observational rainfall data such as CHIRPS or ARC2 captures how much rain has fallen over a
label: BODY

text: defined period of time.
label: BODY

text: •	 The rainfall is measured at weather stations or estimated through satellite or radar imagery.
label: BODY

text: •	 The data can be presented as the total amount of rainfall observed over the period of time,
label: BODY

text: or as below, at or above normal conditions.
label: BODY

text: •	 Datasets that combine station data and satellite or radar imagery are the recommended
label: BODY

text: source of data for humanitarian purposes.
label: BODY

text: •	 Observational rainfall data can be analyzed to answer a range of questions, such as:
label: BODY

text: •	 What areas are currently affected by drought, and how severely?
label: BODY

text: •	 What was the duration of the longest dry spell during the past rainy season?
label: BODY

text: •	 How many days of heavy rainfall were there in the week leading up to the floods?
label: BODY

text: •	 Which area received the most rain last month?
label: BODY

text: •	 How often does an area experience dry spells?
label: BODY

text: •	 How does this year’s rainfall compare to previous years?
label: BODY

text: Key takeaways
label: HH1

text: What is observational rainfall data?
label: HH1

text: Observational rainfall data captures how much rain fell over a defined period of time,
label: BODY

text: ranging from an hour to a day. This data can then be used to calculate the total rainfall for
label: BODY

text: different time periods, such as 5 days (pentad), 10 days (dekad), a week, a month or a season.
label: BODY

text: Observational rainfall datasets can go back decades and have broad geographic coverage,
label: BODY

text: enabling historical trend analysis and comparisons.
label: BODY

text: Observational rainfall data is produced by measuring the amount of rainfall at precise
label: BODY

text: locations, which are called measuring stations or gauges (e.g., the stars in Figure 1 below).
label: BODY

text: Station data is typically obtained from national or regional meteorological services and should
label: BODY

text: only be used in accordance with their guidance. Some of the advantages of station data are
label: BODY

text: that it is accurate at the specific locations, it is collected frequently and it has been collected
label: BODY

text: over the long-term, allowing for trend analysis. On the other hand, station data is only
label: BODY

text: available for specific locations and is subject to bias due to wind, evaporation, and changes in
label: BODY

text: measurement devices. Contact the local or regional meteorological services to learn whether
label: BODY

text: station data is available, where the stations are located, how often the data is updated, and
label: BODY

text: whether historical records are available.
label: BODY

text: CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: Rainfall can also be estimated using satellite or radar images that cover areas several square
label: BODY

text: kilometers wide (e.g., the squares in Figure 1 below). Satellite imagery is typically obtained
label: BODY

text: by global providers and academic or research centers (e.g., the Climate Hazards Center) who
label: BODY

text: share their derived estimates publicly. Satellite or radar images are useful for understanding
label: BODY

text: patterns over larger geographic areas. Some of the advantages of satellite data are that it has
label: BODY

text: extensive geographic coverage, including in remote and inaccessible areas, and that it is shared
label: BODY

text: in a continuous and consistent way. On the other hand, satellite measurements are subject to
label: BODY

text: errors due to cloud contamination, and the data has a shorter historical record.
label: BODY

text: Figure 1. Weather Stations in Zambia (red stars). The grid superimposed onto the map consists of individual
label: BODY

text: boxes, each of which corresponds to a particular location where satellite weather measurements are
label: BODY

text: conducted by certain providers. In this case, the grid is the one used by the ARC2 dataset (see below). The
label: BODY

text: size of each box is 0.1 degree (about 11 km at the equator).
label: BODY

text: In order to help correct for the inaccuracies and errors that are present in the two types of data
label: BODY

text: and take advantage of their individual strengths, research institutions have produced rainfall
label: BODY

text: datasets that combine station and satellite/radar observations. Datasets that combine these
label: BODY

text: observations are the recommended source of data for humanitarian purposes.
label: BODY

text: Observational precipitation data can be presented in various formats, each providing unique
label: BODY

text: insights into precipitation patterns. The most common representation is through absolute
label: BODY

text: values, which reflect the actual amount of precipitation observed at a specific location and time,
label: BODY

text: typically measured in millimeters. Precipitation averages, which are calculated from historical
label: BODY

text: records over a period of typically at least 10 years, can be produced for a specific location,
label: BODY

text: season, or year. A precipitation anomaly represents the deviation from the expected or average
label: BODY

text: precipitation over a particular period, which can be expressed as a difference in millimeters
label: BODY

text: or as a percentage. The purpose of the analysis determines the most useful representation.
label: BODY

text: Absolute values provide insight into the total precipitation received at a location, while
label: BODY

text: anomalies and averages help to understand long-term trends, including dry or wet periods,
label: BODY

text: which is valuable for assessing drought or excessive rainfall conditions severity.
label: BODY

text: CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: 1   https://data.humdata.org/organization/wfp?q=chirps
label: BODY

text: 2   The dataset spans the latitude range 50°S-50°N, and all longitudes.
label: BODY

text: 3   CHIRPS produces a preliminary version of their estimates with a latency of two days. The final version is published in the third week of the
label: BODY

text: following month.
label: BODY

text: Common sources of observational rainfall data
label: HH1

text: Among the many sources of data available, we introduce here two common sources of
label: BODY

text: observational rainfall data, both of which combine station and satellite data: CHIRPS and ARC2.
label: BODY

text: CHIRPS refers to the Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data and is
label: BODY

text: produced by scientists from the US Geological Survey and the Climate Hazards Center at the
label: BODY

text: University of Santa Barbara.  ARC2 refers to Africa Rainfall Climatology Version 2 and it is
label: BODY

text: produced by The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Climate Prediction Center
label: BODY

text: for the Famine Early Warning System. You can access the data directly from these providers, or
label: BODY

text: use the tabular CHIRPS datasets that provides pre-computed rainfall metrics at admin2 and is
label: BODY

text: available on HDX.1
label: BODY

text: COMPARISON OF CHIRPS AND ARC2 OBSERVATIONAL RAINFALL DATA
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Most common uses
label: BODY

text: • Monthly, seasonal, or yearly rainfall
label: BODY

text: monitoring
label: BODY

text: • Included in other tools including
label: BODY

text: those used for drought monitoring and
label: BODY

text: FEWS NET assessments
label: BODY

text: • Trend analysis across years
label: BODY

text: • Near real-time monitoring in Africa
label: BODY

text: • Year-to-year comparisons in Africa
label: BODY

text: Questions to answer with observational rainfall data
label: HH1

text: Observational rainfall data can be used to answer a number of questions and inform decision
label: BODY

text: making in humanitarian operations. Examples include:
label: BODY

text: •	 How much rain fell in the past x days/weeks/months? Observational rainfall datasets
label: HH1

text: provide data on the total amount of rainfall for an area over a discrete period of time, which
label: BODY

text: can be aggregated and used to calculate rainfall over different time intervals.
label: BODY

text: CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: •	 Was the rainfall last month above or below normal? And by how much? Observational
label: BODY

text: rainfall data goes back decades and can therefore be used to determine whether rainfall for
label: BODY

text: a month or a season is above, at or below the historical average.
label: BODY

text: •	 Were there more rainy days this month than last month? Observational rainfall data is
label: HH1

text: available for each day and can be used to determine if it rained or not on a given day and to
label: BODY

text: count the number of dry or wet days during a specific period of time.
label: BODY

text: •	 How many dry spells were there during the past rainy season? How long was the
label: HH1

text: longest dry spell and the heaviest rain streak this past rainy season? Observational
label: BODY

text: rainfall data can be used to detect the occurrence, location and duration of dry spells and
label: BODY

text: prolonged periods of heavy rain.
label: BODY

text: •	 How often in the past decade were more than x millimeters of rainfall measured?
label: HH1

text: Observational rainfall data provides daily rainfall totals in millimeters and can be used to
label: BODY

text: assess how often an area received rain above or below a given threshold.
label: BODY

text: •	 Which region received the most rain last month? Observational rainfall data can be
label: HH1

text: aggregated to provide rainfall totals for larger geographic areas and then used to compare
label: BODY

text: rain for that area.
label: BODY

text: Observational rainfall data cannot answer the following questions:
label: BODY

text: •	 How much will it rain during a period of time in the future? Observational rainfall data is
label: BODY

text: referred to as observational because it describes what happened in the past. It does not tell
label: BODY

text: you anything about future rainfall.
label: BODY

text: •	 Is a severe flooding event about to occur? Are we going through a severe drought?
label: HH1

text: Observational rainfall data does not provide sufficient information to inform you about the
label: BODY

text: risk of flooding in the near future or how severe a drought is likely to be. This is because
label: BODY

text: floods and droughts are complex phenomena caused by several interacting factors and they
label: BODY

text: cannot be explained exclusively by the amount of precipitation.
label: BODY

text: •	 How much rainfall from a given period of time in the past was due to specific tropical
label: BODY

text: storm or typhoon? It is hard to differentiate between the amount of rain caused by
label: BODY

text: average atmospheric conditions and the amount of rain induced by a specific atmospheric
label: BODY

text: phenomenon. As a result, using observational rainfall data alone, it is not possible to say how
label: BODY

text: much rainfall is due strictly to a tropical storm or typhoon. More data is needed to infer the
label: BODY

text: origin of a heavy rainfall event.
label: BODY

text: CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: 4   Learn more: https://www.chc.ucsb.edu/data/chirps
label: BODY

text: 5   Learn more here: https://wiki.chc.ucsb.edu/CHIRPS_FAQ#What_is_the_spatial_density_of_station_data_used_in_CHIRPS.3F
label: BODY

text: Common limitations with observations rainfall data
label: HH1

text: Once you have identified how you want to use the data, it is important to bear in mind some
label: BODY

text: common limitations when conducting your analysis.
label: BODY

text: 1.	 Low-amount or short-duration rainfall may be underreported in certain geographical
label: BODY

text: terrains or during extreme precipitation events.4 Gauges are constantly being improved
label: BODY

text: to reduce error and datasets that combine station and satellite/radar data are best at
label: BODY

text: correcting for these limitations. However, it is still important to keep these limitations in
label: BODY

text: mind, especially when doing analysis that is looking at meteorological events that involve
label: BODY

text: low-amount or short-duration rainfall, such as dry spells.
label: BODY

text: 2.	 There are fewer gauge stations in rural areas and certain developing countries, which
label: BODY

text: means that observational rainfall data is often less accurate in these locations. Fewer gauge
label: BODY

text: stations means that there are fewer measurements for that geographic area, resulting in
label: BODY

text: a less complete picture of what is happening on the ground. Differences in the amount of
label: BODY

text: rainfall received in two locations might be missed if there are not stations to capture rainfall
label: BODY

text: in both locations.5
label: BODY

text: 3.	 Observational rainfall data is usually provided as a raster dataset, where the geographic
label: BODY

text: area is represented by a contiguous grid of cells, or pixels. Each cell represents a discrete
label: BODY

text: area of land, and has a value associated with it but the cells do not neatly fit within
label: BODY

text: administrative boundaries. Calculating rainfall for an administrative area requires an
label: BODY

text: aggregation. The choice of the aggregation method (average, maximum, total etc.) as well
label: BODY

text: as the choice of which cells to include within a given administrative division (all cells fully
label: BODY

text: included, or all cells touched etc.) will impact the results. This is especially true for lower
label: BODY

text: administrative divisions. As a result, adding together the total rainfall for all the districts in a
label: BODY

text: region may not equal the total rainfall calculated for the region.
label: BODY

text: 4.	 If using station data, it is important to bear in mind that stations are easily subject to
label: BODY

text: deterioration and require frequent maintenance, which may affect their accuracy. For
label: BODY

text: this reason, calculating temporal averages, anomalies or trends over long periods of time
label: BODY

text: should be performed with care. When possible, verify with the provider the adequacy of
label: BODY

text: the measurements over long periods of time. This limitation does not apply to CHIRPS and
label: BODY

text: ARC2 datasets, which have been calibrated and combined with satellite observations by
label: BODY

text: climate institutions.
label: BODY

text: 5.	 For station data, differences exist between measuring instruments and quality of their
label: BODY

text: measurements. This may heavily affect comparisons between different locations. Therefore,
label: BODY

text: when performing geographical averages, it is preferable to use radar data, satellite data or
label: BODY

text: observational datasets already calibrated by institutions or universities such as CHIRPS or
label: BODY

text: ARC2.
label: BODY

text: CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: BODY

text: Resources
label: HH1

text: •	 Learn more about the CHIRPS6 and ARC27 observational datasets and/or download data
label: BODY

text: directly from the providers.
label: BODY

text: •	 CHIRPS on HDX8: Download pre-computed tabular data (CSV format) on precipitation totals,
label: BODY

text: averages, anomalies per administrative region.
label: BODY

text: •	 ARC29: Download 1-month or 10-day cumulative precipitation totals (raster, tabular, image
label: BODY

text: data).
label: BODY

text: •	 OCHA AnticiPy10: Download raster (NetCDF) data directly from CHIRPS and ARC2 using a
label: BODY

text: Python library.
label: BODY
